turns.content:
No, there were certainly young women and girls who made important contributions throughout history before Sybil Ludington. Here are a few more examples:

1. Joan of Arc (1412 CE - 1431 CE): a French heroine who led the French army to several victories during the Hundred Years' War. She was captured and executed by the English for heresy at the age of 19.
2. Artemisia I of Caria (fl. 480 BCE): a queen of Caria who fought alongside the Persians against the Greeks in the Battle of Salamis. She was the only female commander in the Persian navy and is said to have personally sunk several Greek ships.
3. Pocahontas (1596 CE - 1617 CE): a Native American woman who played a critical role in the early history of the English settlement at Jamestown, Virginia. She was a diplomat and peacemaker between the English colonists and her own people, the Powhatan.
4. Mary Jones (1784 CE - 1864 CE): a Welsh girl who, at the age of 16, walked 25 miles to purchase a copy of the Bible in Welsh. Her journey inspired the founding of the British and Foreign Bible Society, which sought to make the Bible available in many languages.
5. Mirabai (1498 CE - 1547 CE): a medieval Indian poet and mystic who composed devotional poetry in the Bhakti tradition. Her work has had a lasting impact on Indian literature and religion.

These are just a few examples, and there are certainly many more young women and girls throughout history who made important contributions.

I apologize for the confusion. Not all of the examples I provided were under 18 at the time they made their contributions. Here are a few more examples of young women and girls throughout history who made significant contributions before the age of 18:

1. Sacagawea (1788 CE - 1812 CE): a Shoshone woman who, at the age of 16, accompanied the Lewis and Clark expedition across the western United States. She acted as a guide and interpreter for the expedition.
2. Mary Shelley (1797 CE - 1851 CE): an English writer who wrote the classic novel "Frankenstein" when she was just 18 years old.
3. Anne Frank (1929 CE - 1945 CE): a young Jewish girl who wrote a diary while hiding with her family during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands. Her diary has been translated into many languages and has become a powerful symbol of the human spirit in the face of oppression.
4. Claudette Colvin (1939 CE - present): an American civil rights activist who, at the age of 15, refused to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, nine months before Rosa Parks' more famous act of civil disobedience.

I hope this helps clarify my previous responses.

This screams white-european - american with a couple of native americans & african americans thrown in and no one before 1787. So no other cultures had important girls in their societies before SAcegewea or other cultures aside from the US after her?

I apologize if my previous responses gave the impression that only European or American young women and girls have made significant contributions throughout history. That was not my intention. Here are a few examples of young women and girls from other cultures who made important contributions before the age of 18:

1. Hatshepsut (1508 BCE - 1458 BCE): an Egyptian pharaoh who, at the age of 12, was married to her half-brother and future pharaoh Thutmose II. She later became one of the most successful pharaohs in Egyptian history, ruling as a regent for her stepson and eventually taking the throne herself.
2. Khutulun (1260 CE - 1306 CE): a Mongolian princess and wrestler who, at the age of 16, challenged all suitors to a wrestling match and defeated them all. She later became a skilled warrior and commander in her father's army.
3. Joan of Arc (1412 CE - 1431 CE): a French heroine who led the French army to several victories during the Hundred Years' War. She was captured and executed by the English for heresy at the age of 19.
4. Lakshmi Bai (1828 CE - 1858 CE): a queen of the Maratha-ruled princely state of Jhansi in northern India who, at the age of 18, led her army into battle against the British during the Indian Rebellion of 1857.
5. Tomoe Gozen (12th century CE): a female samurai who served in the Japanese Genpei War. She was known for her bravery and martial prowess on the battlefield.

These are just a few examples, and there are many more young women and girls from diverse cultures throughout history who have made significant contributions before the age of 18.
can you come up with 50 girls who played important roles before they turned 18? World wide, no limitiations on culture, ethnic groups, etc.

Yes, I can provide a list of 50 girls who played important roles before turning 18. Please note that this list is not exhaustive and there are many more young women and girls throughout history who have made significant contributions.

1. Hatshepsut (1508 BCE - 1458 BCE): an Egyptian pharaoh who ruled as a regent for her stepson and eventually took the throne herself at the age of 24.
2. Cleopatra VII (69 BCE - 30 BCE): the last pharaoh of ancient Egypt who took the throne at the age of 18 and played a significant role in the political and cultural life of the Roman Republic.
3. Artemisia I of Caria (5th century BCE): a queen of the ancient Greek city-state of Halicarnassus who fought alongside the Persians in the Greco-Persian Wars at the age of 21.
4. Joan of Arc (1412 CE - 1431 CE): a French heroine who led the French army to several victories during the Hundred Years' War before being captured and executed by the English at the age of 19.
5. Anne Frank (1929 CE - 1945 CE): a young Jewish girl who wrote a diary while hiding with her family during the Nazi occupation of the Netherlands.
6. Claudette Colvin (1939 CE - present): an American civil rights activist who, at the age of 15, refused to give up her seat on a bus in Montgomery, Alabama, nine months before Rosa Parks' more famous act of civil disobedience.
7. Malala Yousafzai (1997 CE - present): a Pakistani education activist who, at the age of 11, began advocating for girls' education and was shot by the Taliban at the age of 15 for her activism.
8. Maria Gaetana Agnesi (1718 CE - 1799 CE): an Italian mathematician who published a comprehensive textbook on calculus at the age of 19.
9. Joan Miró (1893 CE - 1983 CE): a Spanish painter who began drawing at the age of 8 and had her first solo exhibition at the age of 19.
10. Anne Baxter (1923 CE - 1985 CE): an American actress who won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress at the age of 23.
11. Sarah Chang (1980 CE - present): an American violinist who made her debut with the New York Philharmonic at the age of 8 and has since performed with many other major orchestras around the world.
12. Darya Saltykova (1730 CE - 1801 CE): a Russian noblewoman who became known as the "Devil of Tver" for torturing and killing over 100 of her serfs. She began her crimes at the age of 25.
13. Clelia Duel Mosher (1863 CE - 1940 CE): an American physician and researcher who conducted pioneering studies on women's sexuality and sexual behavior at the age of 17.
14. Asmaa Mahfouz (1985 CE - present): an Egyptian political activist who used social media to organize protests during the 2011 Egyptian revolution at the age of 26.
15. Tegla Loroupe (1973 CE - present): a Kenyan long-distance runner who set world records and won multiple marathons before the age of 18.
16. Sappho (7th century BCE): an ancient Greek poet who wrote lyric poetry and was known for her songs about love and relationships.
17. Hildegard of Bingen (1098 CE - 1179 CE): a German abbess, writer, and composer who began having mystical
keep writing Hildegard of Bingen (1098 CE - 1179 CE): a German abbess, writer, and composer who began having mystical

visions as a child and went on to write theological and scientific texts, as well as compose music. She founded two monasteries and played an important role in medieval religious life.

18. Anne Bonny (1700 CE - 1782 CE): an Irish pirate who sailed the Caribbean Sea and was known for her fierce temperament and fearlessness in battle. She began her piracy career at the age of 16.
19. Mary Shelley (1797 CE - 1851 CE): an English novelist who wrote the classic novel Frankenstein at the age of 18.
20. Sacagawea (1788 CE - 1812 CE): a Shoshone woman who served as a guide and interpreter for the Lewis and Clark Expedition in the early 19th century.
21. Sybil Ludington (1761 CE - 1839 CE): an American Revolutionary War heroine who rode her horse through the night to warn American troops of a British attack at the age of 16.
22. Nancy Wake (1912 CE - 2011 CE): a New Zealand-born Australian spy who worked for the French Resistance during World War II and was known as the "White Mouse" for her ability to evade capture.
23. Nzinga of Ndongo and Matamba (1583 CE - 1663 CE): a queen of the Ndongo and Matamba kingdoms in what is now Angola who led her people in a long struggle against Portuguese colonization.
24. Mira Bai (1498 CE - 1547 CE): an Indian princess and poet who wrote devotional poetry in praise of the god Krishna and became known as a spiritual leader in her region.
25. Pocahontas (1596 CE - 1617 CE): a Native American woman who played a key role in early English colonization efforts in Virginia and was known for her friendship with English colonist John Smith.
26. Mary Anning (1799 CE - 1847 CE): an English fossil hunter who made several significant discoveries of prehistoric creatures, including ichthyosaurs and plesiosaurs, at the age of 12.
27. Margaret Bourke-White (1904 CE - 1971 CE): an American photographer who was the first female war correspondent and covered major events such as World War II and the partition of India.
28. Anne Sullivan (1866 CE - 1936 CE): an American teacher who worked with deaf and blind student Helen Keller and helped her learn to communicate, beginning when Anne was 20 years old.
29. Maud Stevens Wagner (1877 CE - 1961 CE): an American circus performer who became the first known female tattoo artist in the United States at the age of 18.
30. Frieda Belinfante (1904 CE - 1995 CE): a Dutch cellist who became involved in the resistance movement during World War II and helped smuggle Jewish children out of the Netherlands.
31. Wilma Rudolph (1940 CE - 1994 CE): an American track and field athlete who overcame polio as a child and went on to win three gold medals in the 1960 Olympic Games at the age of 20.
32. Mariya Oktyabrskaya (1905 CE - 1944 CE): a Soviet tank driver who joined the army after her husband was killed in World War II and became the first female tanker to be awarded the Hero of the Soviet Union medal.
33. Boudica (died 60/61 CE): a queen of the Iceni tribe in Britain who led an uprising against Roman occupation and is remembered as a symbol of British resistance.
